awd_titl_txt: DFG-NSF: Observational Tests of Covariant Emergent Gravity
awd_abstract_narration:
General Relativity provides a well-tested, accurate description of gravitational phenomena over a large range of distances, but it remains a non-quantum theory incompatible with the Standard Model of particle physics. The development of a quantum theory of gravity is thus a central goal of fundamental physics. Observational clues arise from puzzles such as the "dark matter" and "dark energy" problems. These indicate an excess of attraction beyond what can be explained by the gravity of visible mass in galaxies (hence dark matter), and a net repulsion (dark energy) that drives the expansion rate of the universe to accelerate. It is conceivable that these diverse phenomena are related and may emerge from the quantum foundations of gravity. This work will develop and explore the observable consequences of Covariant Emergent Gravity, a theory that may provide a joint explanation for these as-yet ill-understood observations.

This project aims to develop and test a new explanation for dark matter and dark energy. Verlinde has proposed the idea of gravity as an emergent phenomenon, but many of the consequences of this idea remain unexplored. A theoretical shortcoming is that it is not generally covariant. Recently, Hossenfelder addressed this problem by developing Covariant Emergent Gravity (CEG). CEG necessarily introduces terms beyond those already present in Emergent Gravity. The team proposes to develop this theory and to investigate whether CEG can be consistent with observations of galactic rotation curves. In particular, it will derive the formulas that govern the appropriate limit of the theory and numerically solve them to apply to real galaxies. This work must be carried out in the non-trivial, non-spherical case of the finite thickness cylindrical geometry appropriate to spiral galaxies. If the CEG hypothesis is incorrect, this work should readily falsify it. If there is some merit to it, it could point the way towards a fresh interpretation and potential resolution of the long-standing dark matter and dark energy problems, and provide insight into the nature of quantum gravity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to develop and test covariant emergent gravity as a potential alternative to cosmic dark matter. A combination of advances resulted in a result of broader applicability that constrains other covariant gravity theories and also novel forms of dark matter. The key advances are a combination of personnel development, theory development, and observational advances, specifically

 

Personnel development: this project supported 

- the dissertation work of Tobias Mistele, new Ph.D.

- the further career development of co-I Sabine Hossenfelder

 

Theory development: this project

- explored the hypothesis of Covariant Emergent Gravity (CEG)

- showed CEG was unlikely to be viable on purely theoretical grounds

 

Observational advances: 

- rigorous analysis of weak gravitational lensing data for isolated galaxies

- use of weak lensing data to extend the dynamic range of the radial acceleration relation

- application of the resulting radial acceleration relation as a test of 

(i) Superfluid dark matter

(ii) Aether Scalar Tensor theory

These hypotheses are in tension with the observations. Superfluid dark matter is practically falsified while Aether Scalar Tensor theory survives only in a narrow range of parameter space with some additional special pleading.

 

These developments are reported in eight papers published in the refereed literature.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Stacy S Mcgaugh

Image
  • The observed radial acceleration relation (points) and that predicted by Aether Tensor Scalar theory (lines). The data show no hint of the mass-dependent features predicted by this theory.
    T. Mistele, S. McGaugh, S. Hossenfelder
    Creative Commons
    Stacy S Mcgaugh
    Test of Aether Scalar Tensor theory
